#### Section 2: Skin-depth effects
Atoms and molecules near the surface of matter in a condensed phase, for
example a solid or liquid, are relatively high in potential energy. Such
atoms would prefer to be interacting with atoms like them in the bulk,
as opposed to interacting with the vacuum, air, or a solvent medium. In
the bulk, atoms are engaged in van der Waals interactions and other
favorable electrostatic or metallic forms of bonding. The lack of
favorable interactions lead to the most pronounced effects for the atoms
near the surface. In fact, the atoms don't have to be exactly at the
surface to have reduced intensity of interactions with atoms in the
bulk. So-called **multibody effects** owing to the alignment of dipoles
produce cooperative attraction that extends some small number of
atoms---i.e., a few nanometers---into the bulk. This thickness, called
the "skin depth," leads to a number of disparate and important
phenomena, which we discuss below.

### 10.2.1. Cohesive energy loss

We saw in chapter 2, the molar cohesive energy of a condensed phase of
matter is derived from summing up the individual interactions of each
atom or molecule with its neighbors. Given the presence of longer range,
multibody effects, it turns out that the molar cohesive energy of a
solid or liquid is around a factor of 7.22 times the intermolecular pair
potential for atoms or molecules of the substance at contact. The total
expression is

(Equation 10.1) $$E_{cohesive}=6w(\sigma)N_{A}$$

(Equation 10.2) $$E_{cohesive}=7.22w(\sigma)N_{A} 
        % (considering long-range effects)$$

where $N_A$ is Avogadro's number. The factor of $N_A$, which has units
of mol$^{-1}$, ensures that the final quantity has units of energy per
mole.

Note that the weird factor of 7.22 in equation (10.2) is an empirical
(experimentally determined) correction to the value of 6 shown in
equation (10.1). We would obtain a value of 6 if we considered a liquid
or solid in a close-packed arrangement, where the number of nearest
neighbors was 12. (We get from 12 to 6 because each atom contributes
half the bonding energy to each interaction with each one of its nearest
neighbors. We divide by two to prevent over accounting, and thus arrive
at 6.) The correction to a factor of 7.22 is a consequence of the fact
that the van der Waals interactions actually extend a few atoms away
from the reference atom.

The value of the molar cohesive energy given by equation (10.2) holds
true for a large slab of a material. That is, when the vast majority of
atoms are contained in the bulk of the sample, away from the surface.
However, what about for nanoscale materials? That is, what happens as we
consider a nanoscale structure, whose composition is dominated by the
properties of atoms close to the surface? If we are, say 10 atoms or
more into the surface (i.e., 3 to 5 nm deep), the environment
experienced by those atoms is pretty much like those in the bulk.
However, as we proceed toward the surface, that extra factor of 1.22
(i.e., 7.22$-$`<!-- -->`{=html}6) which adds to the cohesive energy
begins to shrink. Once we get to the top surface, the attractive
energies due to long range interactions disappear. Moreover, the factor
of 6 will also drop, because at the surface, there are no longer 12
nearest neighbors!

So, the atoms in the "skin" of a liquid or solid experience less overall
favorable interactions than do atoms in the bulk. Consider for example a
thin film of gold with a thickness of 20 nm. If skin-depth effects
penetrate to a distance of 5 nm, then half of the atoms---if one takes
into account the top and bottom surface---will lie within the skin!
Since the atoms in the skin have reduced interaction energies, the
cohesive energy of the entire object decreases. This decreased cohesion
has many consequences, including reduction in melting point in solids,
and decreased surface tension in liquids. These phenomena will be
described below.

### 10.2.2. Melting point depression

The most obvious manifestation of this reduction in cohesive energy
density is in the melting point, which for solid nanoparticles is
reduced by

(Equation 10.3) $$T_R=T_{bulk}(1-\frac{\lambda}{R})$$

where $T_R$ is the melting temperature of the nanoparticle, $T_{bulk}$
is the melting point of a bulk, macroscopic slab of the material,
$\lambda$ is the skin depth (1-3 nm for metals) and $R$ is the height or
thickness of a nanoparticle. The effects of melting point depression in
nanoparticles can be exploited through **sintering**. That is, fusing
together as a solid object using heat or even light, at much lower
temperatures and energies than samples of the same material in the bulk.

The effect of melting point depression also manifests in
nanoelectronics, especially in cases where nanostructures are expected
to withstand relatively large currents. I remember one time in graduate
school when I was fabricating nanowires of various metals for use in
chemical and biochemical sensors. In one set of experiments, I was
trying to measure the conductivity of metallic nanowires by connecting
them to a **source measure unit** (SMU, see Chapter 9, where we used an
SMU to measure the properties of a solar cell) and measuring current
flow as a function of applied voltage. So, I painstakingly stenciled the
locations of electrodes at the termini of each nanowire, and deposited
the electrodes through the hand-made stencil masks by thermal
evaporation. Upon performing the electrical measurements, each wire
showed conductivity for only a few moments and then became an open
circuit (i.e., effectively infinite resistance). I couldn't figure out
what was happening until I looked at the failed nanowires under SEM.
What I observed in each case was the same: a broken region of the
nanowire a few hundred nanometers in width, in which each end of the
nanowire adopted a bulbous shape like two opposing lollipops (see Figure
(10.2)).

(Figure 10.2) 
>>>image(lollipops.png.0)

Why did the breakage occur and why did the termini of the wires adopt
such an unusual shape? It turned out that the electrical current led to
a phenomenon called **joule heating**, which occurs when electrons
travel fast through a conductor.[^10.2.1] The wire got so hot that it melted
in (most likely) the thinnest region. A thicker wire would have been
able to withstand much greater currents without melting. The reason is
that for a thinner and thinner wire, \<\<100 nm, an increasing fraction
of atoms are at the surface. These atoms are there for missing some of

### 10.2.3. Surface tension reduction

Recall from Chapter 4 that the surface tension arises from the increase
in potential energy that occurs when a molecule in a liquid it rises
from the bulk to the surface. That is, it takes work to expand a surface
in an amount proportional to the amount of new surface created. In other
words, the work needed is proportional to the number of atoms or
molecules that were forced to the surface as a result of expansion. The
difference in potential energy between a sample with a large surface
area vs. the same sample with a small surface area creates a force which
acts to contract the surface. From the standpoint of individual atoms
and molecules, there is a driving force for them to dive back into the
bulk so as to have all of their valencies satisfied. This constant
gradient and potential energy from high at the surface to low in the
bulk acts to remove atoms from the surface and thus to produce a
contractile force: the surface tension.

unsatisfied valancies. Just as in the case with melting point
depression, there is a skin depth effect. The resulting surface tension
is given by the Tolman equation, as follows in equation (10.4):

(Equation 10.4)
$$\gamma_R=\gamma_{\infty}\frac{1}{1+\frac{\lambda}{R}}$$

thickness---especially as the thickness approaches the skin depth---is
that there is an overall less energetic benefit for an atom to retreat
to the "bulk," *since the atoms in the bulk are still in the skin depth
and thus already quite unsatisfied*. So, they don't get the full
energetic benefit of submerging themselves and are thus less inclined to
do so. Think about our conception of force being the negative rate of
change of the potential energy with respect to a geometric change, that

#### Section 4: Brownian motion
When small particles are placed in fluids such as liquids and gases,
they are subject to lots of collisions---billions to quadrillions per
second, depending on the size of the particle---from the molecules that
make up the medium. These collisions transfer kinetic energy to the
particles, which change the speed and trajectory of the particles. For
sufficiently large particles, collisions coming from every direction
tend to cancel out, since there is no preferred direction which would
propel movement in one direction. However, for smaller particles, the
statistically fewer number of collisions means that the collisions are
less likely to balance out, and overall movement can be observed.
Indeed, the mobility of a spherical particle increases with the inverse
of its radius. You will learn much more about Brownian motion in a later
course (if you continue in nanoengineering), but suffice it to say now
that its effect on the diffusion of nanoparticles in liquids and in the
atmosphere is largely an effect of scaling, with small particles ending
up much farther from their places of origin, even in nominally
undisturbed regions the absence of directional currents in the gas or
liquid medium (see Figure (10.5)).

amazing properties. Many of these properties arise from quantum
mechanical effects (light-matter interaction), entropic effects (the

importance in energy, manufacturing, and human health.

#### Section 2: Skin-depth effects
Atoms and molecules near the surface of matter in a condensed phase, for
example a solid or liquid, are relatively high in potential energy. Such
atoms would prefer to be interacting with atoms like them in the bulk,
as opposed to interacting with the vacuum, air, or a solvent medium. In
the bulk, atoms are engaged in van der Waals interactions and other
favorable electrostatic or metallic forms of bonding. The lack of
favorable interactions lead to the most pronounced effects for the atoms
near the surface. In fact, the atoms don't have to be exactly at the
surface to have reduced intensity of interactions with atoms in the
bulk. So-called **multibody effects** owing to the alignment of dipoles
produce cooperative attraction that extends some small number of
atoms---i.e., a few nanometers---into the bulk. This thickness, called
the "skin depth," leads to a number of disparate and important
phenomena, which we discuss below.

### 10.2.1. Cohesive energy loss

We saw in chapter 2, the molar cohesive energy of a condensed phase of
matter is derived from summing up the individual interactions of each
atom or molecule with its neighbors. Given the presence of longer range,
multibody effects, it turns out that the molar cohesive energy of a
solid or liquid is around a factor of 7.22 times the intermolecular pair
potential for atoms or molecules of the substance at contact. The total
expression is

(Equation 10.1) $$E_{cohesive}=6w(\sigma)N_{A}$$

(Equation 10.2) $$E_{cohesive}=7.22w(\sigma)N_{A} 
        % (considering long-range effects)$$

where $N_A$ is Avogadro's number. The factor of $N_A$, which has units
of mol$^{-1}$, ensures that the final quantity has units of energy per
mole.

Note that the weird factor of 7.22 in equation (10.2) is an empirical
(experimentally determined) correction to the value of 6 shown in
equation (10.1). We would obtain a value of 6 if we considered a liquid
or solid in a close-packed arrangement, where the number of nearest
neighbors was 12. (We get from 12 to 6 because each atom contributes
half the bonding energy to each interaction with each one of its nearest
neighbors. We divide by two to prevent over accounting, and thus arrive
at 6.) The correction to a factor of 7.22 is a consequence of the fact
that the van der Waals interactions actually extend a few atoms away
from the reference atom.

The value of the molar cohesive energy given by equation (10.2) holds
true for a large slab of a material. That is, when the vast majority of
atoms are contained in the bulk of the sample, away from the surface.
However, what about for nanoscale materials? That is, what happens as we
consider a nanoscale structure, whose composition is dominated by the
properties of atoms close to the surface? If we are, say 10 atoms or
more into the surface (i.e., 3 to 5 nm deep), the environment
experienced by those atoms is pretty much like those in the bulk.
However, as we proceed toward the surface, that extra factor of 1.22
(i.e., 7.22$-$`<!-- -->`{=html}6) which adds to the cohesive energy
begins to shrink. Once we get to the top surface, the attractive
energies due to long range interactions disappear. Moreover, the factor
of 6 will also drop, because at the surface, there are no longer 12
nearest neighbors!

So, the atoms in the "skin" of a liquid or solid experience less overall
favorable interactions than do atoms in the bulk. Consider for example a
thin film of gold with a thickness of 20 nm. If skin-depth effects
penetrate to a distance of 5 nm, then half of the atoms---if one takes
into account the top and bottom surface---will lie within the skin!
Since the atoms in the skin have reduced interaction energies, the
cohesive energy of the entire object decreases. This decreased cohesion
has many consequences, including reduction in melting point in solids,
and decreased surface tension in liquids. These phenomena will be
described below.

### 10.2.2. Melting point depression

The most obvious manifestation of this reduction in cohesive energy
density is in the melting point, which for solid nanoparticles is
reduced by

(Equation 10.3) $$T_R=T_{bulk}(1-\frac{\lambda}{R})$$

where $T_R$ is the melting temperature of the nanoparticle, $T_{bulk}$
is the melting point of a bulk, macroscopic slab of the material,
$\lambda$ is the skin depth (1-3 nm for metals) and $R$ is the height or
thickness of a nanoparticle. The effects of melting point depression in
nanoparticles can be exploited through **sintering**. That is, fusing
together as a solid object using heat or even light, at much lower
temperatures and energies than samples of the same material in the bulk.

The effect of melting point depression also manifests in
nanoelectronics, especially in cases where nanostructures are expected
to withstand relatively large currents. I remember one time in graduate
school when I was fabricating nanowires of various metals for use in
chemical and biochemical sensors. In one set of experiments, I was
trying to measure the conductivity of metallic nanowires by connecting

What I observed in each case was the same: a broken region of the
nanowire a few hundred nanometers in width, in which each end of the

effects of quantum confinement (e.g., the particle in a box model),
interactions arising from transient dipoles (i.e., London dispersion),
and effects arising from statistical physics (i.e., entropy). However,
some of the most important properties of nanostructures arise simply
because they are small. There are two vantage points from which to view
these effects of confinement and scaling. The first is from a
**continuum** vantage point in which the molecular details are ignored.
Consequences of this viewpoint include the fact that a hippopotamus must
have thicker legs relative to its mass than does a spider. The second
vantage point is **atomistic** or **molecular**; it predicts---among
other things---that the melting point of small objects is lower than

One of the most interesting and ubiquitous effects of shrinking
materials down to the nanoscale has nothing to do with van der Waals
forces, or quantum mechanics, but with math. Not even complicated math
like calculus and statistics, but simple geometry. Consider a critical
linear dimension, call it $R$, which could be the radius of a circle,
sphere, or cylinder, or the length of the edge of a cube. The dimensions
of objects scale with different factors of $R$. The length scales with
$R$, the area (including surface area) scales with $R^2$, and the
volume---and therefore the mass---scale with $R^3$. Many of the most
important properties of nanomaterials come not strictly from physics but
rather from the ways that these quantities scale relative to one another
as $R$ shrinks to nanoscale dimensions.

Consider the effect of decreasing the radius of a spherical particle.
The surface area is equal to $4\pi R^2$, while the volume is
$\frac{4}{3}\pi R^3$. Thus, the surface area to volume ratio decreases
in proportion to $1/R$. So, as $R$ approaches "nano," the ratio of
surface area to volume blows up.

The consequences of this relationship---and others that derive from it,

nearly every aspect of the mechanics of nanostructured materials and
composites. Moreover such effects dictate the properties of nominally
"continuum materials," such as polymers, steel, and concrete. The reason
is that the microstructure (a historical term for what should really be
called the *nanostructure*) of such materials is dictated by processing,
thermal history, and kinetics of solidification, as mediated by effects
that manifest on the nanoscale.

interesting effects of size confinement arise only from the arithmetic:

whereas an **atomistic** or **molecular** model contains information
about the internal structure. Thus, in addition to the consequences of

scaled down because real materials are made of atoms. The simplest

volume increases, an increasing fraction of the object's atoms are found

surface have different properties than those found in the **bulk**
(i.e., interior) of solids and liquids. For example, atoms near the
surfaces of catalytic particles tend to be more reactive than those in

surface and those in the bulk give rise to well-known effects like

electrons at the surfaces of metals also give rise to **surface plasmon

### 10.1.2. Area to volume and strength-to-weight: hippos and spiders

The mass of an object scales with its volume, which scales roughly with
the cube of one of its linear dimensions. In contrast, the strength of
an object scales with its cross-sectional area perpendicular to the
load. To illustrate, consider a hippopotamus approximated as a sphere
(as is customary). If the radius of the hippopotamus is 1 meter, and has
roughly the same density as water
($1000\frac{\text{kg}}{\text{m}^{3}}$), then the volume is
$\frac{4}{3}\pi R^3$ or $\sim$`<!-- -->`{=html}4m$^3$ and the mass is
$\sim$`<!-- -->`{=html}4,000 kg or 4 metric tons. That's a lot of
weight! To support this heft, its legs must be as thick as tree trunks
to keep that huge bulk aloft.

On the other hand, a spider is much smaller than a hippopotamus.[^10.1.1] If
the radius of a daddy long legs spider is 1 mm (0.001 m), then its
volume is $\sim$`<!-- -->`{=html}4 $\times 10^{-9}$ m$^3$ and its mass
is $\sim$`<!-- -->`{=html}4 mg. Given this small mass, it is no wonder
that spiders can get away with having such skinny legs! Nevertheless, if
a spider were simply embiggened to have the same 1 m radius as the
hippo, its legs would still be comically thin, and the poor spider would
collapse under its own weight.

The reason is that the strength of a bone (or muscle, in fact) increases
more slowly with its size than does the weight. Specifically, the
strength of a bone/muscle scales in proportion to its cross sectional
area. (The cross sectional area of the muscle is taken to be
perpendicular to its axis of contraction or extension.) For a muscle
approximated as a cylinder (we like making these simple approximations
to make life easier), this area is equal to $\pi R^2$. So, if you scale
up a spider, its weight increases with $R^3$ while the strength of each
leg increases only with $R^2$. Note, again, that this strength-to-weight
scaling law is also purely a mathematical effect; it is completely
ignorant of the molecular or structural details that give rise to the
strength of an object. The relationship certainly doesn't know anything
about the mechanism of how muscles operate. The same scaling law applies
when designing furniture or skyscrapers: bigger things need thicker
legs.

Of course, by creating composite materials made of long nanostructures
whose lengths are arranged parallel to the axis of loading, we can cheat
a little bit. If you have ever been to San Francisco and visited the
Golden Gate Bridge,[^10.1.2] there is a monument consisting of the cross
section of one of the huge cables from which the bridge is suspended.
The striking thing about this cross section is that the cable is made of
nearly 30 thousand little cables, each one of which was strengthened by
drawing during processing of the metal. Such strengthening would have
been impossible to achieve if the cable---whose full diameter is almost
1 m---were made using one huge solid chunk of metal. Not only would it
be nearly impossible to manufacture, but it would be much weaker.
Moreover, a single defect might easily compromise the integrity of the
entire structure. Such an outcome would be catastrophic for a busy
bridge, but is entirely avoided in a composite cable.

While the Golden Gate Bridge is quite geriatric, the use of composite
materials pervades modern technology. For example, carbon composite
plastic materials contain **carbon fibers**. These fibers are made from
conventional polymeric fibers whose non-carbon atoms have been blasted
off using heat in an inert atmosphere. What results is a graphitic
structure (think graphene or carbon nanotubes) which when placed in a
polymer such as epoxy or nylon can increase the strength by several
orders of magnitude. Carbon-fiber reinforced polymers thus have among
the best strength-to-weight ratios of any engineered materials. Thus,
while we cannot escape the mathematical inevitability of the poor
strength of materials with small cross sections, we can definitely work
within its constraints to engineer materials with greatly increased
strength. These examples illustrate the importance of the internal
structure of materials in determining its bulk properties. After all,
you would never make the girders for a skyscraper out of eggshells.

a spider were simply embiggened to have the same 1 m radius as the
hippo, its legs would still be comically thin, and the poor spider would
collapse under its own weight.

The reason is that the strength of a bone (or muscle, in fact) increases
more slowly with its size than does the weight. Specifically, the
strength of a bone/muscle scales in proportion to its cross sectional
area. (The cross sectional area of the muscle is taken to be
perpendicular to its axis of contraction or extension.) For a muscle
approximated as a cylinder (we like making these simple approximations
to make life easier), this area is equal to $\pi R^2$. So, if you scale
up a spider, its weight increases with $R^3$ while the strength of each
leg increases only with $R^2$. Note, again, that this strength-to-weight
scaling law is also purely a mathematical effect; it is completely
ignorant of the molecular or structural details that give rise to the
strength of an object. The relationship certainly doesn't know anything
about the mechanism of how muscles operate. The same scaling law applies
when designing furniture or skyscrapers: bigger things need thicker
legs.

Of course, by creating composite materials made of long nanostructures
whose lengths are arranged parallel to the axis of loading, we can cheat
a little bit. If you have ever been to San Francisco and visited the
Golden Gate Bridge,[^10.1.2] there is a monument consisting of the cross
section of one of the huge cables from which the bridge is suspended.
The striking thing about this cross section is that the cable is made of
nearly 30 thousand little cables, each one of which was strengthened by
drawing during processing of the metal. Such strengthening would have
been impossible to achieve if the cable---whose full diameter is almost
1 m---were made using one huge solid chunk of metal. Not only would it
be nearly impossible to manufacture, but it would be much weaker.
Moreover, a single defect might easily compromise the integrity of the
entire structure. Such an outcome would be catastrophic for a busy
bridge, but is entirely avoided in a composite cable.

While the Golden Gate Bridge is quite geriatric, the use of composite
materials pervades modern technology. For example, carbon composite
plastic materials contain **carbon fibers**. These fibers are made from
conventional polymeric fibers whose non-carbon atoms have been blasted
off using heat in an inert atmosphere. What results is a graphitic
structure (think graphene or carbon nanotubes) which when placed in a
polymer such as epoxy or nylon can increase the strength by several
orders of magnitude. Carbon-fiber reinforced polymers thus have among
the best strength-to-weight ratios of any engineered materials. Thus,
while we cannot escape the mathematical inevitability of the poor
strength of materials with small cross sections, we can definitely work
within its constraints to engineer materials with greatly increased
strength. These examples illustrate the importance of the internal
structure of materials in determining its bulk properties. After all,
you would never make the girders for a skyscraper out of eggshells.

#### Section 2: Skin-depth effects
Atoms and molecules near the surface of matter in a condensed phase, for
example a solid or liquid, are relatively high in potential energy. Such
atoms would prefer to be interacting with atoms like them in the bulk,
as opposed to interacting with the vacuum, air, or a solvent medium. In
the bulk, atoms are engaged in van der Waals interactions and other
favorable electrostatic or metallic forms of bonding. The lack of
favorable interactions lead to the most pronounced effects for the atoms
near the surface. In fact, the atoms don't have to be exactly at the
surface to have reduced intensity of interactions with atoms in the
bulk. So-called **multibody effects** owing to the alignment of dipoles
produce cooperative attraction that extends some small number of
atoms---i.e., a few nanometers---into the bulk. This thickness, called
the "skin depth," leads to a number of disparate and important
phenomena, which we discuss below.

### 10.2.1. Cohesive energy loss

We saw in chapter 2, the molar cohesive energy of a condensed phase of
matter is derived from summing up the individual interactions of each
atom or molecule with its neighbors. Given the presence of longer range,
multibody effects, it turns out that the molar cohesive energy of a
solid or liquid is around a factor of 7.22 times the intermolecular pair
potential for atoms or molecules of the substance at contact. The total
expression is

(Equation 10.1) $$E_{cohesive}=6w(\sigma)N_{A}$$

(Equation 10.2) $$E_{cohesive}=7.22w(\sigma)N_{A} 
        % (considering long-range effects)$$

where $N_A$ is Avogadro's number. The factor of $N_A$, which has units
of mol$^{-1}$, ensures that the final quantity has units of energy per
mole.

Note that the weird factor of 7.22 in equation (10.2) is an empirical
(experimentally determined) correction to the value of 6 shown in
equation (10.1). We would obtain a value of 6 if we considered a liquid
or solid in a close-packed arrangement, where the number of nearest
neighbors was 12. (We get from 12 to 6 because each atom contributes
half the bonding energy to each interaction with each one of its nearest
neighbors. We divide by two to prevent over accounting, and thus arrive
at 6.) The correction to a factor of 7.22 is a consequence of the fact
that the van der Waals interactions actually extend a few atoms away
from the reference atom.

The value of the molar cohesive energy given by equation (10.2) holds
true for a large slab of a material. That is, when the vast majority of
atoms are contained in the bulk of the sample, away from the surface.
However, what about for nanoscale materials? That is, what happens as we
consider a nanoscale structure, whose composition is dominated by the
properties of atoms close to the surface? If we are, say 10 atoms or
more into the surface (i.e., 3 to 5 nm deep), the environment
experienced by those atoms is pretty much like those in the bulk.
However, as we proceed toward the surface, that extra factor of 1.22
(i.e., 7.22$-$`<!-- -->`{=html}6) which adds to the cohesive energy
begins to shrink. Once we get to the top surface, the attractive
energies due to long range interactions disappear. Moreover, the factor
of 6 will also drop, because at the surface, there are no longer 12
nearest neighbors!

So, the atoms in the "skin" of a liquid or solid experience less overall
favorable interactions than do atoms in the bulk. Consider for example a
thin film of gold with a thickness of 20 nm. If skin-depth effects
penetrate to a distance of 5 nm, then half of the atoms---if one takes
into account the top and bottom surface---will lie within the skin!
Since the atoms in the skin have reduced interaction energies, the
cohesive energy of the entire object decreases. This decreased cohesion
has many consequences, including reduction in melting point in solids,
and decreased surface tension in liquids. These phenomena will be
described below.

### 10.2.2. Melting point depression

The most obvious manifestation of this reduction in cohesive energy
density is in the melting point, which for solid nanoparticles is
reduced by

(Equation 10.3) $$T_R=T_{bulk}(1-\frac{\lambda}{R})$$

where $T_R$ is the melting temperature of the nanoparticle, $T_{bulk}$
is the melting point of a bulk, macroscopic slab of the material,
$\lambda$ is the skin depth (1-3 nm for metals) and $R$ is the height or
thickness of a nanoparticle. The effects of melting point depression in
nanoparticles can be exploited through **sintering**. That is, fusing
together as a solid object using heat or even light, at much lower
temperatures and energies than samples of the same material in the bulk.

The effect of melting point depression also manifests in
nanoelectronics, especially in cases where nanostructures are expected
to withstand relatively large currents. I remember one time in graduate
school when I was fabricating nanowires of various metals for use in
chemical and biochemical sensors. In one set of experiments, I was
trying to measure the conductivity of metallic nanowires by connecting
them to a **source measure unit** (SMU, see Chapter 9, where we used an
SMU to measure the properties of a solar cell) and measuring current
flow as a function of applied voltage. So, I painstakingly stenciled the
locations of electrodes at the termini of each nanowire, and deposited
the electrodes through the hand-made stencil masks by thermal
evaporation. Upon performing the electrical measurements, each wire
showed conductivity for only a few moments and then became an open
circuit (i.e., effectively infinite resistance). I couldn't figure out
what was happening until I looked at the failed nanowires under SEM.
What I observed in each case was the same: a broken region of the
nanowire a few hundred nanometers in width, in which each end of the
nanowire adopted a bulbous shape like two opposing lollipops (see Figure
(10.2)).

their long and short range bonds with nearby atoms, and the overall

### 10.2.3. Surface tension reduction

Recall from Chapter 4 that the surface tension arises from the increase
in potential energy that occurs when a molecule in a liquid it rises
from the bulk to the surface. That is, it takes work to expand a surface
in an amount proportional to the amount of new surface created. In other
words, the work needed is proportional to the number of atoms or
molecules that were forced to the surface as a result of expansion. The
difference in potential energy between a sample with a large surface
area vs. the same sample with a small surface area creates a force which
acts to contract the surface. From the standpoint of individual atoms
and molecules, there is a driving force for them to dive back into the
bulk so as to have all of their valencies satisfied. This constant
gradient and potential energy from high at the surface to low in the
bulk acts to remove atoms from the surface and thus to produce a
contractile force: the surface tension.

Consider now that it is not only the atoms at the very surface that have
unsatisfied valancies. Just as in the case with melting point
depression, there is a skin depth effect. The resulting surface tension
is given by the Tolman equation, as follows in equation (10.4):

(Equation 10.4)
$$\gamma_R=\gamma_{\infty}\frac{1}{1+\frac{\lambda}{R}}$$

where the variables are defined in the description of equation (10.3).
The reason that the surface tension decreases with
thickness---especially as the thickness approaches the skin depth---is
that there is an overall less energetic benefit for an atom to retreat
to the "bulk," *since the atoms in the bulk are still in the skin depth
and thus already quite unsatisfied*. So, they don't get the full
energetic benefit of submerging themselves and are thus less inclined to
do so. Think about our conception of force being the negative rate of
change of the potential energy with respect to a geometric change, that
is, equation (10.5):

(Equation 10.5) $$F(D) = \frac{-dW(D)}{dD}$$

Where, in this case, you can think about the dimension $D$ as the size
of the liquid surface, and $dD$ as an incremental increase or decrease
in this dimension. Looking at this equation, we see that the force
(i.e., the surface tension) is smaller when the change in energy,
$dW(D)$, is small with respect to the change in dimension, $dD$. Despite
the reduction in surface tension for ultrathin films and droplets of
liquid, it can still be a powerful enough force to wreak havoc on small
structures.

#### Section 3: Surface tension acting on the nanoscale
There are probably very few instances in most most of your everyday
lives when you are aware of the effects of surface tension. On a rainy
day, you might be glad that your car windshield had a coating of
hydrophobic material. The coating, e.g., "Rain-X," allows water droplets
to bead up instead of spread out so that windshield wipers can push the
water to the side. You may also notice that, when you are brushing your
teeth and turn the water off slowly, the formerly continuous stream of
water coming from the faucet pinches off into discrete little droplets.
You may also be aware of the sticky feeling of your skin against your
clothes on a humid day. The stickiness is due to capillary forces. These
forces, though annoying, are easy to break free from with human-level
strength.

For objects on the nanoscale however, the effects of surface tension can
easily overwhelm. Because of the scaling law that predicts that surface
area goes as $1/R$ with respect to volume and therefore mass, small
objects have a lot of surface area on which surface tension may act, but
not much mass to weigh it down. For this reason, it is easy for even
weak forces like the surface tension to push nanoparticles around. Also,
it doesn't take a very thick film of liquid to exert a surface
tension---only a couple of atoms, or until the skin depth were
surpassed. It wouldn't matter after that point if the layer of water
were as thick as the ocean. Below, we explore some of the consequences
of surface tension acting on small objects. We will see that the effects
can be treated either as something to be exploited in an engineering
application, or something to be avoided, as they can easily mess up our
carefully designed manufacturing processes.

### 10.3.1. Water striders

A **water strider** is a type of insect that lives on the surface of
still water in ponds or at slow-moving edges of creeks. They "ski" along
the water surface in little bursts. It can be difficult to see them
unless they are moving. One of the most striking things about the
appearance of water striders is the way in which little circles seem to
appear at their feet. These circles are dimples or depressions made in
the surface of the water, whose tension is responsible for holding the
animal above water.[^10.3.1]

Hold on a second! Doesn't the surface tension exerts a force *in the
plane* of the surface of the water? Nevertheless, the direction of the
force appears to be pointing up, against the force of gravity. The key
to the apparent buoyancy of a water strider is in the depressions made
in the water by its feet. In fact, the feet are coated in nanoscopic
hairs which together gently rest on the surface of the water, instead of
piercing it. The upward force of surface tension is actually a
consequence of the concave dimples made by the feet. See Figure (10.3)
for the free body diagram.

The surface tension exists tangentially to all of the nanoscopic

The Brazilian pygmy gecko lives in the rainforests of, you got it,

### 10.3.3. Critical point drying in microfabrication

Most of the processes for top down micro---and nano---fabrication
discussed in Chapter 12 require aqueous solvents, or at least other
solvents with high surface tension. Unfortunately, as the solvents
evaporate, the formation of solvent menisci between high aspect ratio
features causes them to bend toward one another, stick to each other
irreversibly, collapse, or even break (see Figure (10.4), below).

(Figure 10.4) 
>>>image(breakage.png.0)

Remember that a liquid film does not have to be very thick in order to
exert significant surface tension. To avoid the potentially damaging
effects of surface tension, solvents are commonly removed using a
**critical point dryer**. This device uses high heat and pressure to
turn the solvent into a **supercritical fluid**, a phase of matter which
has the properties of both of gas and liquid, and in which the densities
of the two phases are equal. Critically, pun intended, eliminating the
boundary between liquid and gas also eliminates the surface tension and
the menisci that damages structures by tugging on adjacent features.

In critical point drying, which is used in the fabrication of sensors
for microelectromechanical systems (MEMS),[^10.3.2] the water is usually
rinsed away with a solvent having a somewhat lower surface tension than
water, such as acetone. The structure containing the acetone is placed
in a chamber with carbon dioxide. When super critical CO$_2$ is
introduced into the system, it disperses the remaining polar solvent and
thus eliminates the liquid bridges between nanostructures. Thus, all of
the remaining fluid can be removed without the potentially damaging
effects of surface tension.[^10.3.3]

#### Section 1: Scaling laws: A consequence of math or physics?
Nanoscale structures derive many of their unique properties from weird
effects of quantum confinement (e.g., the particle in a box model),
interactions arising from transient dipoles (i.e., London dispersion),
and effects arising from statistical physics (i.e., entropy). However,
some of the most important properties of nanostructures arise simply
because they are small. There are two vantage points from which to view
these effects of confinement and scaling. The first is from a
**continuum** vantage point in which the molecular details are ignored.
Consequences of this viewpoint include the fact that a hippopotamus must
have thicker legs relative to its mass than does a spider. The second
vantage point is **atomistic** or **molecular**; it predicts---among
other things---that the melting point of small objects is lower than
that of large objects of the same material because a greater proportion
of the atoms of a small object are near the surface. For a video primer
to this chapter, visit 
>>>video(https://youtu.be/H3U8BQoQ-Ok)

One of the most interesting and ubiquitous effects of shrinking
materials down to the nanoscale has nothing to do with van der Waals
forces, or quantum mechanics, but with math. Not even complicated math
like calculus and statistics, but simple geometry. Consider a critical
linear dimension, call it $R$, which could be the radius of a circle,
sphere, or cylinder, or the length of the edge of a cube. The dimensions
of objects scale with different factors of $R$. The length scales with
$R$, the area (including surface area) scales with $R^2$, and the
volume---and therefore the mass---scale with $R^3$. Many of the most
important properties of nanomaterials come not strictly from physics but
rather from the ways that these quantities scale relative to one another
as $R$ shrinks to nanoscale dimensions.

Consider the effect of decreasing the radius of a spherical particle.
The surface area is equal to $4\pi R^2$, while the volume is
$\frac{4}{3}\pi R^3$. Thus, the surface area to volume ratio decreases
in proportion to $1/R$. So, as $R$ approaches "nano," the ratio of
surface area to volume blows up.

The consequences of this relationship---and others that derive from it,
e.g., the ratio of strength to weight and strength to volume---affect
nearly every aspect of the mechanics of nanostructured materials and
composites. Moreover such effects dictate the properties of nominally
"continuum materials," such as polymers, steel, and concrete. The reason
is that the microstructure (a historical term for what should really be
called the *nanostructure*) of such materials is dictated by processing,
thermal history, and kinetics of solidification, as mediated by effects
that manifest on the nanoscale.

### 10.1.1. Continuum vs. molecular scaling effects

As we have alluded in the introduction to this chapter, many of the
interesting effects of size confinement arise only from the arithmetic:

not the structure is even made of atoms! These effects are the result of

whereas an **atomistic** or **molecular** model contains information
about the internal structure. Thus, in addition to the consequences of

volume increases, an increasing fraction of the object's atoms are found

surface have different properties than those found in the **bulk**

surface and those in the bulk give rise to well-known effects like
surface tension (recall from Chapter 4). The interactions of conduction
electrons at the surfaces of metals also give rise to **surface plasmon
resonance (SPR)**, which is used widely in applications from
"invisibility cloaking" to chemical and biochemical sensing. These and
other effects of downsizing dimensions to the nanoscale are everywhere,
and we will continue to encounter them as we look around at phenomena
